So first of all, the internet in a nutshell, where is BGP used that everybody knows about?
You have edge devices on a network communicating to other edge devices on another network.
And those devices communicate via data packets that are routed from one network to another
via routers.
And those routers need to know how to get these packets from network A to network B.
And BGP is the routing protocol that allows these routers to exchange routing information
and kind of say, you know, I'm responsible for networks X, Y, and Z with this specific
IP block and so on.
And as Simone mentioned, we did some research in the past into TCP IP stacks and basically
the protocols used at the edge devices.
And now we wanted to focus on the router side of things and on BGP, right?
So BGP, routing for the internet, it's the protocol that is used to exchange routing
and reachability information among autonomous systems.
And an autonomous system is a block of IPs that is leased to an organization by a register
for a certain time period, right?
Just like you have in the domain name system, a domain is assigned to somebody for a certain
period of time.
Similarly, an autonomous system does that for a block of IPs.
So BGP is the protocol that is used to advertise autonomous system numbers and peer networks
that are considered to be part of an autonomous system.
And it can be either used internally within an autonomous system, so called internal BGP,
or externally called external BGP with peers on the internet.
And BGP is the protocol that makes routing decisions based on paths, network policies,
rule sets, and so on to kind of decide how a packet gets from one device in one network
to another device in a network all the way on the other side of the world, potentially.
But as I mentioned at the beginning, there are other use cases nowadays for BGP beyond
the typical network, internet scale routing.
So data centers in the past decade have grown to such a large size that many organizations
use BGP internally these days for routing internally in their own data centers, right?
BGP is also used for MPLS, layer 3 VPNs, across different organization sites.
So a same organization that has sites across the globe and wants to connect them via a
VPN, sometimes use BGP to exchange specific information for making that VPN possible.
It's also embedded in custom appliances that go sometimes in internet service providers
or internet exchanges.
Some content providers like Netflix, for instance, they have their specific way to treat traffic
and do that more efficiently, and they kind of embed these appliances directly in some
ISPs.
And, you know, there are emerging use cases like load balancing, and people get creative
and they're using BGP for a lot of other use cases these days.
So I just want to kind of open your mind to the fact that everything that we mentioned,
you know, BGP being used for the internet routing cases is the typical use case.
It's what it's mostly used for still these days, but there are many other uses for it.
So in summary, why I'm saying that is because BGP security per se is not just for internet
service providers and internet exchanges anymore, right?
Any organization will potentially be using BGP and should be responsible for the security
of BGP within their networks.
So the basics of BGP, right?
So BGP is a protocol with a kind of a simple state machine.
You have six states there, a limited set of messages that, you know, transition from
those states.
So basically you have peers that are waiting.
They set up a connection.
There is a keep-alive message that keeps that connection open that is sent every X seconds.
There is a notification when some error happens, or there's an update message to update the
routing tables between the peers.
And the packets are also relatively straightforward, right?
So you have a package that has a header with a length and a type of a message, and then
you have the content of the message, which is also not super complex, right?
So what potentially could go wrong with BGP?
So well, the fact, and going back to kind of the basics, and this is something that
is well known, that BGP, like DNS, like many other early internet protocols, has no built-in
security, right?
Like authentication, authorization mechanisms, and things like that.
So mistakes or intentional attacks that lead to network outages and traffic redirection
in BGP happen frequently, right?
The situation has been improving in past years, and we'll talk in the next slide a little
bit about some of the traditional routing BGP security, but the fact is that still thousands
of incidents happen per year of route leaks and hijacks, where basically a network or
a router originates in the BGP jargon, right?
So basically claims to be responsible for a prefix or a set of IPs that is owned by
a network, another network, without the permission of that other network, right?
And that, in some cases, is used by attackers to make packets go through specific networks
that an attacker controls and can maybe read or tamper with packets.
So in many cases, it's actually accidental, and in other cases, it potentially is an actual
attack, especially when countries or more riskier countries, let's say, are involved
in this kind of activity.
So traditional BGP security has to do mainly with filtering out this incorrect or malicious
routing information, doing origin validation, so verifying that a network that announces
a route is actually authorized to do it, and path validation, ensuring that no unauthorized
network is actually diverting traffic via a false route.
So there are many techniques, protocols, and ideas these days to do that, and I invite
you to have a look at those specific techniques, like RPKI, BGPsec, and so on.
But again, most of BGP security, until now, the typical discussion around BGP security
is always this kind of routing security, right?
But what about vulnerabilities in BGP implementations themselves?
So when BGP fails because of software implementations, it has happened in the past also, specific
incidents where, because of different implementations and the way that some BGP implementations
would parse messages, routers would actually crash and cause network outages and things
like that.
So a specific example that happened in 2019 with the FR routing BGP implementation, and
we're going to talk a little bit further about FR routing in the rest of this presentation,
it led to some network outages around Asia and Australia.
The fact was that some researchers were trying some new features in kind of an academic test,
but the fact is that not every router was ready to parse those new types of messages.
So why do we think it's important then to research these BGP implementations, right?
So the latest systematized work that we found about testing BGP implementations was 20 years
ago, actually, exactly 20 years ago in 2003.
It was a presentation at Black Hat, a team at Cisco that looked at both implementation
and configuration of BGP across different vendors.
They did the work that actually turned out in the end, we kind of followed some of their
paths.
So they created a fuzzer, they analyzed seven implementations and they found four new CVs
at that time, right?
But they also concluded that at that time misconfigurations were more dangerous than

There has been a lot of improvement in BGP and in the actual implementation of BGP security

Also in 2007, a team at Juniper analyzed specifically the update message handling across several

So they saw seven vendors affected, 10 not affected, and 25 that never responded to the

We found, meaning those exist already, right?
Those were well-known.
We found in the National Vulnerability Database, and some of them include remote code executions.

And there are many different implementations of routing platforms, of network operating

So let's talk about the new research that we've done.
So first let's talk about our methodology.

We also looked at the previous implementations where vulnerabilities were found, so we selected

So this led us to have both open-source and closed-source targets.
And so we tried to start with static analysis, but of course for closed-source software it's
a lot more difficult, so we decided to try to develop a fuzzer that will help us in analyzing
these specific implementations.
And in the end we also used the fuzzer for open-source implementations.
So first the manual analysis we did led us to find multiple interesting things.
First we found some issues in the design of BGP, because it's a very old protocol, I think
the first RFC about BGP is from 1989.
So for example there is a lot of type length value parameters inside BGP messages, which
means that when doing parsing of BGP messages you first need to extract some fields to get
information on the next fields to extract, and it brings a lot of exception handling
and parsing quirks that make everything more difficult.
Also optional parameters are a mess, and another thing is that sometimes peer response to any
open messages.
So the open messages are the messages used to first establish a BGP connection, so it's
called BGP peering, and sometimes we even have update messages that are accepted by
peers without prior connection, BGP connection establishment.
So it's a big attack surface on the internet, and this is why we decided to focus mainly
on open and update messages.
So first for open messages we examined multiple implementations, we found two things, so first
most of the implementations they have the BGP running in the user mode, which means
that we first have the TCP connection establishment because TCP handshake is handled by the kernel,
so we cannot have filtering on the connections before looking at the BGP messages themselves,
but except for Cisco IOS where the BGP daemon is running in the kernel.
And so for one implementation in particular, so FA routing, we found that some parameters
are parsed before the origin of the messages is validated.
So we only had to spoof the source IP address to trace some attacks.
Now about the fuzzing, so first to explain quickly what is a fuzzer, it's basically a
program that will generate automatically malformed input to send to a target, and then we just
wait for the target to crash at some point.
And so in our case we used BooFuzz, which is an open source framework to make fuzzers,
and so with this fuzzer we only had to describe roughly what is BGP, like we did some test
cases by explaining to the fuzzer what BGP message looks like, so that it's able to generate
messages that look like BGP but are in fact malformed and contain possibly dangerous values.
And we also implemented an RPC monitor.
So the goal of the RPC monitor is to, we install it alongside of the BGP daemon, and so the
goal is to wait, because as soon as the BGP daemon will crash, the RPC monitor will report
the crash to the fuzzer, so the fuzzer will know that a specific payload made the daemon
crash and will save the payload and restart automatically the BGP daemon.
And it's open source, so if you want to contribute you can look at the code.
And so now for the demo of the fuzzer.
So on the terminal on the right you will have the BGP daemon running, and on the left you
will have the fuzzer.
So first we launch the BGP daemon, it's now waiting for connections.
Next we launch the fuzzer, and the fuzzer will just generate many malformed messages
attempting to crash the BGP daemon.
And it will soon crash.
So now the BGP daemon crashed, and we will see that the fuzzer generated a Python file
which contains the payload that made the BGP daemon crash.
And next we just have to launch the BGP daemon again, but this time inside the debugger,
so we can look at the specific issues that made the daemon crash.
So now we launch the BGP daemon inside the debugger, and it's now waiting for connections.
And now we will execute again the same payload that made it crash the first time.
Now it crashed again, and we will look at the backtrace to see in which function the
problem is.
And I don't know if you can see, but basically there's a function called BGP open receive,
which is a function that takes care of the open message parsing.
So with this fuzzer, we found in total three vulnerabilities, which are denial of service.
They are all due to the optional parameters in BGP.
They were quite easy to find, and they are similar to the Cisco IOS vulnerabilities that
Daniel introduced previously.
And also we wanted to mention that the FRO team were really quick in fixing the issues,
so it was really great working with them.
So for the first vulnerability, we have an if condition that will look if the optional
parameters are activated, basically.
And if they are activated, it will try to get the next byte in the packet, but without
checking beforehand if this next byte exists.
So we just had to send a packet that ends with the values that the if is looking for,
and we will get a read out of bound of one byte.
And just below in the same function, we have exactly the same issue two times.
The second vulnerability is again very similar, but this time we have a check to see if we
can read two bytes more.
But in case of optional parameter, we actually read three bytes instead of two, which is
again a read out of bounds.
And the third one is also the same.
It's a very similar code from the previous one, but it's in another function.
Right, thanks.
So kind of summarizing the results, or the new results, besides the things that I mentioned
before with previous vulnerabilities, so we do see that still there are some popular implementations
that are too permissive.
So in some cases, not necessarily filtering out correctly unwanted open messages.
And in other cases, even parsing these messages before filtering them, before discarding them,
before they actually realize whether it's coming from a wanted source or an unwanted
source.
On the other hand, some of this parsing can lead to denial of service vulnerabilities
and can be abused by attackers to take down some routers, sorry, some BGP implementations
on the routers and potentially the routing tables and so on.
So let's talk a little bit about the impact of these issues.
So any of these three new CVs leads to denial of service on a vulnerable BGP peer, as I
mentioned, dropping the BGP sessions and routing tables and rendering the peer unresponsive
for some time.
BGP is typically a daemon, so it will restart after a certain timeout, but this denial of
service can be prolonged by just repeatedly sending its one packet, right, that crashes
the server.
Two issues out of those three can be triggered before.
As I was mentioning, FRouting validates BGP identifier and ASN field, so even before knowing

So in this case, an attacker only needs to spoof a valid IP address to send this message.
And beyond these vulnerabilities, if we look at typical IPv4 scans, like show them the

Not all of those are running BGP necessarily, because Quagga is a routing suite that has

And there are also more than 1,000 hosts running FRouting directly, right?
There are also implications of this type of vulnerability, because it deals with an open
source project, and because it's a component that will be embedded in other components

There are kind of supply chain issues and supply chain implications here, right?
So if you take FRouting, it's an open source project that came from a previous project
that is even older, and it currently has more than 1,000 forks on GitHub.
So we worked very well with the project developers to fix it on the main branch of the project,
let's say.
But downstream forks, it's difficult to know when, how they will actually apply those patches.
Also, this type of component ends up in different network operating systems.
So I have some examples there, Dant, Sonic, Cumulus, they are popular network operating
systems that are also open source and use FRouting as a specific component.
So again, it's difficult to know when and which versions will actually apply those patches.
Those operating systems, in turn, are used by networking vendors, and that is what ends
up in the networks of end users, right?
So between the patches on the original project and the end users, there's a long way to go
before sometimes these patches are applied, right?
So almost any kind of research into vulnerabilities in open source these days has this kind of
consideration, right?
Supply chain is a big emerging issue, and we need to be aware of that.
But if we talk about risk mitigation also, I want to go back to the beginning of the
talk and say that routing security is still very important and still not solved, and specifically
for internet service providers or for people who are dealing with BGP on a day-to-day basis,
there are several good guides of security and basically good implementations of BGP
out there, right?
So Manners is a good project, there are specific RFCs for BGP operations and security, there
are guidelines from NIST and several other agencies about implementing the proper routing
security mechanisms.
But threat actors, as we mentioned in the beginning, have been attacking network infrastructure
devices directly, so don't forget software vulnerabilities, right?
That is specifically for BGP but also for other protocols, other implementations.
Those devices can be vulnerable, so you need to identify those devices on your network
that may be using BGP and assess those vulnerabilities and patch when possible, taking into account
all the supply chain issues that we mentioned.
Also the fuzzer that we released, it's open on GitHub and it comes with the prepared test
cases for the CVEs that we found, so if we want to test that against any implementation
that you have that is using FR routing for whatever reason, you can run those scripts
directly and if you want to test any new implementation, you're free and welcome to extend the fuzzer
as well or to use it out of the box on the implementation that you are interested in,
and we would really be glad to hear about results or ways to improve the fuzzer and so on.
So going to takeaways and future work, right?
So BGP is still crucial for the internet and it's widely used beyond internet service providers
and internet exchanges.
Unlike embedded TCP IP stacks, which we looked at in another project, BGP implementations
have matured very well and in general do not have obvious mistakes, right?
But some popular BGP implementations do have vulnerabilities or are too permissive.
That's the main conclusion here.
Network function disaggregation will make some BGP implementations, some open implementations
very popular that's already happening, so it's very important to keep the security of
those projects in check and keep doing research on those.
Threat actors are exploiting these kinds of issues and mitigation should not only be about
routing security and should not be only delegated to your ISP, right?
It's everyone's responsibility, let's say, to make sure that things are running securely.
In terms of future work, I think keep fuzzing new versions and new implementations, improving
the fuzzer with new test cases and so on is very important.
And exploring other parts of the routing infrastructure and the routing attack surface as well, like
other routing protocols, looking glass servers, remote control functions and so on is important.
And it would be very interesting to understand what specific for which campaigns these threat
actors are leveraging these BGP denials of service.
So that's it.
Thank you very much for your time and happy to take some questions now.
